{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox boxer | name = Gervonta Davis | image =-Photo-credit-Idris-Erba-Mayweather-Promotions.jpg | caption = | realname = | nickname = Tank | weight = [[Super featherweight]] | height = 5 ft 5+1/2 in<ref name=stats2018>[[Showtime Championship Boxing]] tale of the tape prior to the [[Jesús Cuellar]] fight.</ref> | reach = 67+1/2 in<ref name=stats2018/> | nationality = American | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1994|11|7}} | birth_place = [[Baltimore, Maryland]], U.S. | style = [[Southpaw stance|Southpaw]] | total = 20 | wins = 20 | KO = 19 | losses = 0 | draws = | no contests = }}
'''Gervonta Davis''' ({{IPAc-en|dʒ|ər|ˈ|v|ɒ|n|t|eɪ}} {{respell|jər|VON|tay}}; born November 7, 1994) is an American [[professional boxer]]. He is a two-time [[super featherweight]] world champion, having held the [[WBA (Super)]] title since April 2018 and previously the [[International Boxing Federation|IBF]] title in 2017. As of July 2018, Davis is ranked as the world's second best active super featherweight by ''[[The Ring (magazine)|The Ring]]'' magazine,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ringtv.com/ratings/?weightclass=282|title=Ratings - The Ring|work=The Ring|access-date=2018-07-05|language=en-US}}</ref> the [[Transnational Boxing Rankings Board]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tbrb.org/all-rankings/|title=RANKINGS {{!}} Transnational Boxing Rankings Board|website=www.tbrb.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-05}}</ref> and [[Boxrec]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://boxrec.com/en/ratings?r%5Bcountry%5D=&r%5Bdivision%5D=Super+Featherweight&r%5Bsex%5D=M&r%5Bstance%5D=&r%5Bstatus%5D=a&r_go=|title=Boxrec Rankings|work=Boxrec|access-date=2018-07-05}}</ref>
==Early life and amateur career== Davis has been training at Upton Boxing Center since he was five years old.<ref name="17Facts">{{cite news|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/sports/bal-17-facts-about-baltimore-boxing-champion-gervonta-davis-20170115-story.html|title=17 facts about Baltimore boxing champion Gervonta Davis|first=Mark|last=Selig|publisher=Baltimore Sun|date=January 15, 2017|accessdate=April 7, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://gervontadavis.com/about|title=Gervonta Davis – Biography|website=GervontaDavis.com}}</ref> Davis is trained by Calvin Ford who was the inspiration for the character [[Dennis "Cutty" Wise]] on the hit [[HBO]] television series, ''[[The Wire]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2015/04/a-boxing-school-in-baltimore-is-fighting-for-the-citys-soul|title=A boxing school in Baltimore is fighting for the city's soul|author=Chris Korman|date=April 29, 2015|work=USA Today}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/sports/bs-sp-gervonta-davis-0720-20130718-story.html|title=Local boxer Gervonta Davis says he's fighting 'to bring happiness back to Baltimore'|author=Ryan Hood|date=July 19, 2013|work=The Baltimore Sun}}</ref> Davis had a very successful amateur career, winning many national championships. He won the 2012 National [[Golden Gloves]] Championship,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goldengloves.com/history|title=National Golden Gloves Past Champions|website=GoldenGloves.com}}</ref> three straight National [[Silver Gloves]] Championships from 2006–2008,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nationalsilvergloves.org/hallofchampions/?c=5|title=National Silver Gloves Hall of Champions|website=NationalSilverGloves.com}}</ref> two National Junior Olympics gold medals, two National [[Police Athletic League]] Championships, and two Ringside World Championships, among others. Davis finished his illustrious amateur career with an impressive record of 206–15.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ringtv.craveonline.com/news/381459-new-faces-gervonta-davis|title=New Faces: Gervonta Davis|author=Anson Wainwright|date=February 18, 2015|work=The Ring Magazine}}</ref>
Davis originally hails from the [[Sandtown-Winchester, Baltimore|Sandtown-Winchester]] community in West Baltimore, which is one of the most crime-ridden areas of the city.<ref name=17Facts/> He attended [[Digital Harbor High School]], a local [[magnet school]], but dropped out to focus on his career. He later earned his secondary degree through a [[General Educational Development|GED]] program.<ref name=17Facts/>
==Professional career== ===Early fights=== Davis made his debut at the age of 18 on February 22, 2013 against Desi Williams, who had a professional record of no wins and 4 losses, all by stoppage. The fight took place at the [[D.C. Armory]] in [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] on the undercard of IBF super lightweight fight between [[Lamont Peterson]] and [[Kendall Holt]]. Davis won the bout via 1st round knockout. By August 2014, Davis had recorded 8 wins and no losses, with all wins coming inside the distance. Davis was taken the six round distance for the first time in October 2014 against veteran 28 year old [[Germán Meraz|German Meraz]] (47–31–1, 25 KOs). Davis knocked Meraz down in rounds 3 and 5, and went on to win a unanimous decision, winning all rounds on the three scorecards (60–52, 60–52, 60–52).
On February 20, 2015 at the [[CONSOL Energy Center]] in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]], Davis became the first person to stop Puerto Rico’s Israel Suarez (4–4–2, 1 KO), winning in devastating fashion with a first round knockout.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thaboxingvoice.com/gervonta-tank-davis-stops-suarez-in-one-round|title=Gervonta "Tank" Davis Stops Suarez In One Round|date=February 22, 2015|website=ThaBoxingVoice.com}}</ref>
On May 22, 2015 at [[The Claridge Hotel (Atlantic City)|The Claridge Hotel]] in [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]], Davis scored a technical knockout against Alberto Mora (5–3, 1 KO) of Mexico 1 minute, 14 seconds into the fight. The normally durable Mora was stopped for the first time in his career.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/sports/bs-sp-gervonta-davis-boxing-0527-20150527-story.html|title=Gervonta 'Tank' Davis wins by first-round TKO in Atlantic City|date=May 27, 2015|work=The Baltimore Sun}}</ref> On September 12, 2015 at the [[MGM Grand Garden Arena]] in [[Las Vegas]] on [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] as part of the [[Floyd Mayweather vs. Andre Berto]] undercard, Davis defeated Recky Dulay (8–1, 5 KOs) of the Philippines in only 94 seconds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/boxing/story/_/id/13640308/roman-martinez-retains-title-draw-orlando-salido|title=Roman Martinez retains title in draw with Orlando Salido|author=Dan Rafael|date=September 14, 2015|website=ESPN.com}}</ref> On October 30, 2015 at [[The Venue at UCF]] in [[Orlando, Florida]] on [[Bounce TV]], Davis defeated former featherweight world titleholder [[Cristobal Cruz]] (40–18–4, 24 KOs) of Mexico.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/boxing/story/_/id/14035583/jermell-charlo-wins-easy-asks-world-title-shot|title=Scorecard: Jermell Charlo wins easy, asks for world title shot|author=Dan Rafael|date=November 2, 2015|website=ESPN.com}}</ref>
On December 18, 2015 at the [[Palms Casino Resort]] in [[Las Vegas]] on [[Spike TV]], Davis scored a ninth-round knockout of Mexico's Luis Sanchez (17–4–1, 5 KOs).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/boxing/story/_/id/14414842/luis-ortiz-impresses-destruction-bryant-jennings|title=Scorecard: Luis Ortiz impresses in destruction of Bryant Jennings|author=Dan Rafael|date=December 21, 2015|website=ESPN.com}}</ref> On April 1, 2016 at the D.C. Armory on [[Spike TV]], Davis defeated Guillermo Avila (16–5, 13 KOs) by knockout in the sixth round.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/boxing/story/_/id/15116184/adrien-broner-triumphs-calls-floyd-mayweather|title=Adrien Broner triumphs, calls out Floyd Mayweather|author=Dan Rafael|date=April 2, 2016|website=ESPN.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://stiffjab.com/adrien-broner-gervonta-davis-score-knockouts-at-d-c-armory-e491e1b09249|title=Adrien Broner, Gervonta Davis Score Knockouts at D.C. Armory|author=Seamus McNally|date=April 4, 2016|work=Stiff Jab}}</ref> On June 3, 2016 at the Seminole Hard Rock Hotel and Casino in [[Hollywood, Florida]] as part of a [[Premier Boxing Champions]] card, Davis knocked out [[Marco Macías|Mario Antonio Macias]] (28–18, 14 KOs) of Mexico with his first punch of the fight, which lasted only 41 seconds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/sports/bs-sp-digest-0604-20160604-story.html|title=Gervonta Davis wins fight in Florida on first-round KO|author=Sam Rogers|date=June 4, 2016|work=The Baltimore Sun}}</ref>
===IBF super featherweight champion===
==== Davis vs. Pedraza ==== On November 15, 2016 ESPN announced that Davis would challenge for the [[List of IBF world champions#Junior lightweight|IBF junior lightweight]] title against undefeated [[José Pedraza (boxer)|José Pedraza]] (22–0, 12 KOs) on January 14, 2017 at the [[Barclays Center]] in [[Brooklyn]] on [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]]. The fight would take place as an undercard fight to the super middleweight world title unification fight between [[James DeGale|James Degale]] and [[Badou Jack]]. The IBF granted Pedraza an exception to fight Davis, as he had a mandatory fight against British boxer [[Liam Walsh (boxer)|Liam Walsh]] looming. prior to the fight being announced, Mayweather promotions matchmaker tried to make a deal for Davis to fight titleholder [[Jason Sosa]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/boxing/story/_/id/18051178/jose-pedraza-defend-130-pound-crown-gervonta-davis-jan-14|title=Pedraza to defend title vs. Mayweather protege Davis|work=ESPN.com|access-date=2017-08-26}}</ref> Davis defeated Pedraza in a seventh-round knockout to win the IBF junior lightweight title.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/boxing/story/_/id/18476170/gervonta-davis-takes-junior-lightweight-belt-away-jose-pedraza|title=Gervonta Davis takes junior lightweight belt away from Jose Pedraza|author=Dan Rafael|date=January 15, 2017|website=ESPN.com}}</ref> After the fight, Davis said that he had studied the early career of his promoter and mentor, [[Floyd Mayweather Jr.]], in order to stay composed. He said, "I had a lot of experience [from the amateur ranks], but I learned how to keep my composure. Floyd told me to stay calm, and I studied Floyd Mayweather [videos] when he was 'Pretty Boy.' My uppercut was my best shot, and it was landing all night. It felt really good to fight the way I did. I could take it and dish it out." Mayweather Jr. himself enthusiastically branded his protégé as the future of boxing. For the fight, Davis earned $75,000 compared to Pedraza, who earned the lions share of $225,000, in what was his third defence. At the time of stoppage, Davis was ahead 59–55 on all three judges scorecards.<ref>[http://www.boxingscene.com/gervonta-davis-this-i-studied-pretty-boy-floyd-not-money--112676 "Gervonta Davis: For This I Studied 'Pretty Boy' Floyd, Not 'Money'"]. BoxingScene. January 15, 2017. Retrieved January 21, 2017.</ref> The bout took place on the undercard of the super middleweight unification fight between [[James DeGale]] and [[Badou Jack]] and averaged 344,000 viewers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/degale-jack-drew-an-average-454000-viewers-on-showtime--112785|title=DeGale-Jack Drew an Average of 454,000 Viewers on Showtime - Boxing News|website=www.boxingscene.com|language=en-us|access-date=2017-05-23}}</ref>
==== Davis vs. Walsh ==== On May 7, 2017 it was announced Davis would travel to [[London|London, England]] for his first title defence. The news came from [[Frank Warren (promoter)|Frank Warren]], promoter of challenger [[Liam Walsh (boxer)|Liam Walsh]] (21–0, 14 KO), who was also ranked number 1 by the IBF. The fight was scheduled to take place on May 20, 2017 and billed as '''Show me the Money''<nowiki/>'.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.badlefthook.com/2017/3/7/14845544/gervonta-davis-vs-liam-walsh-set-for-may-20th-in-london|title=Davis vs. Walsh set for May 20th|date=2017-03-07|website=Bad Left Hook|access-date=2017-05-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxnation.com/boxing-news/gervonta-davis-vs-liam-walsh-blockbuster-confirmed-for-may-20th-at-the-copper-box-arena/|title=Gervonta Davis vs. Liam Walsh blockbuster confirmed for May 20 at the|website=www.boxnation.com|language=en|access-date=2017-05-12}}</ref> At the official weigh in on May 19, Davis made weight on his third attempt. His first attempt, although he was naked, he weighed two ounces over. He was then given the two hours to attempt to lose the extra weight, although he came back earlier thinking he had lost it. He eventually met the limit of 130 pounds on his third attempt.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/gervonta-davis-makes-weight-on-third-try-walsh-fight--116734|title=Gervonta Davis Makes Weight on Third Try for Walsh Fight - Boxing News|website=www.boxingscene.com|language=en-us|access-date=2017-05-19}}</ref> Davis stopped Walsh in the third-round to retain his IBF title. After two cagey rounds, which were controlled by Davis, he came out with power punches at the start of the third. Walsh's legs looked to give way and David pounced with accurate hooks to the head, eventually dropping Walsh. Walsh beat the count on unsteady legs. The fight resumed and Davis went on the attack again, connected with every shot he threw, forcing referee Michael Alexander to stop the fight. The time of stoppage was 2 minutes and 11 seconds of round 3.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/gervonta-davis-takes-out-liam-walsh-three-rounds-results--116783|title=Gervonta Davis Takes Out Liam Walsh in Three Rounds - Boxing News|website=www.boxingscene.com|language=en-us|access-date=2017-05-23}}</ref> Many at ringside believed the stoppage was premature, including Walsh, "That was a bad stoppage. He's very fast and very active but it was too quick. He won fair and square but in England sometimes they stop the fight too early." Davis believed he would have caught Walsh eventually.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/boxing/story/_/id/19426231/floyd-mayweather-protege-gervonta-davis-outclasses-liam-walsh-london|title=Davis outclasses Walsh in three rounds|work=ESPN.com|access-date=2017-05-23}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/boxing/39989209|title=Gervonta Davis retains IBF super-featherweight title by stopping Liam Walsh|date=2017-05-20|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2017-05-23|language=en-GB}}</ref> The fight was shown live on Showtime in the USA averaging 228,000 viewers and peaking at 253,000 viewers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.badlefthook.com/2017/5/24/15684896/crawford-diaz-sets-the-bar-for-hbo-ratings-this-year|title=Crawford-Diaz sets the bar for HBO ratings this year|date=2017-05-24|website=Bad Left Hook|access-date=2017-05-24}}</ref>
==== Davis vs. Fonseca ==== According to [[TMZ|TMZ Sports]] in early July 2017, it was reported that Davis would feature in the co-main event of [[Floyd Mayweather Jr. vs. Conor McGregor]] on August 26, 2017 at the [[T-Mobile Arena]] in Paradise, Nevada.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2720323-gervonta-davis-will-fight-in-co-main-event-at-mayweather-vs-mcgregor|title=Gervonta Davis Will Fight in Co-Main Event at Mayweather vs. McGregor|last=Chiari|first=Mike|work=Bleacher Report|access-date=2017-07-08|language=en-US}}</ref> On July 29, The Ring Magazine reported that Davis would likely defend his IBF title against former WBO champion [[Román Martínez (boxer)|Román 'Rocky' Martínez]], whose last fight was a knockout loss to Vasyl Lomachenko in June 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ringtv.com/505704-gervonta-davis-likely-defend-title-roman-martinez-aug-26/|title=Gervonta Davis likely to defend title against Roman Martinez on Aug. 26 - The Ring|date=2017-07-29|work=The Ring|access-date=2017-07-29|language=en-US}}</ref> On August 10, Ringtv reported that Davis would instead fight unbeaten prospect [[Francisco Fonseca (boxer)|Francisco Fonseca]] (19-0-1, 13 KOs), who at the time was ranked number 7 by the IBF. According to some sources, the potential fight with Martínez was dropped due to notice and Martínez would not have had enough time to make the 130 pound limit.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ringtv.com/513684-gervonta-davis-defend-title-francisco-fonseca-aug-26/|title=Gervonta Davis to defend title against Francisco Fonseca on Aug. 26 - The Ring|date=2017-08-10|work=The Ring|access-date=2017-08-16|language=en-US}}</ref> Prior to the fight being announced, the IBF had ordered Fonseca to fight their number 3 ranked [[Billy Dib]] (42-4, 24 KOs) in a final eliminator, as they were the two highest ranked available.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/dib-vs-fonseca-eliminator-set-gervonta-davis-mandatory--119055|title=Dib vs. Fonseca Eliminator To Set Gervonta Davis' Mandatory - Boxing News|website=www.boxingscene.com|language=en-us|access-date=2017-08-16}}</ref> At the weigh in, Fonseca came in at the 130 pound limit. Davis showed up an hour late and came in at 132 pounds, 2 pounds over the weight limit. Davis declined to weigh in after two hours, forcing the IBF to strip him of the title. The title was declared vacant, but the title would be still up for grabs if Fonseca secured victory.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.boxingnewsonline.net/gervonta-davis-loses-ibf-title-on-the-scales/|title=Gervonta Davis loses IBF title on the scales - Boxing News|date=2017-08-26|work=Boxing News|access-date=2017-08-26|language=en-US}}</ref> In what was billed as an easy fight for Davis, he won the fight via knockout in round 8, with the ending being controversial. The final punch appeared to be an illegal punch to the back of the head to Fonseca and referee Russell Mora counted him out 39 seconds into the round. After the fight, Davis mocked Fonseca.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ringtv.com/515298-gervonta-davis-stops-francisco-fonseca-mayweather-mcgregor-card/|title=GERVONTA DAVIS STOPS FRANCISCO FONSECA ON MAYWEATHER-MCGREGOR CARD}}</ref> Fonseca appeared hurt before the knockout blow, which Davis, who was being booed by the crowd, explained to [[Jim Gray (sportscaster)|Jim Gray]] of Showtime in the post fight interview, “I actually caught him with a body shot before that and he was hurt. So he took advantage of me hitting him in the back of his head and went down.” With the win, Davis scored his 10th straight knockout victory. Due to Davis winning the fight, the IBF title remained vacant.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/gervonta-davis-knocks-out-francisco-fonseca-results--119878|title=Gervonta Davis Knocks Out Francisco Fonseca in Eight - Boxing News|website=www.boxingscene.com|language=en-us|access-date=2017-08-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/boxing/story/_/id/20468285/badou-jack-demolishes-nathan-cleverly-win-light-heavyweight-belt|title=Mayweather-McGregor undercard recap: Jack demolishes Cleverly to win light heavyweight belt|work=ESPN.com|access-date=2017-08-27}}</ref> For the fight, Davis earned a purse of $600,000 compared to the amount $35,000 that Fonseca received.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloodyelbow.com/2017/8/25/16207748/purses-revealed-for-all-fighters-on-floyd-mayweather-conor-mcgregor-card-ufc-boxing-mma+&cd=2&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=uk|title=Purses revealed: Mayweather $100M, McGregor $30M|work=Bloody Elbow|access-date=2017-12-31}}</ref>
=== WBA (super) super featherweight champion ===
==== Davis vs. Cuellar ==== On November 15, 2017 Leonard Ellerbe, CEO of Mayweather Promotions announced that Davis would be making his in ring return in the first quarter of 2018 alongside stablemate Badou Jack. He also revealed that Davis would fight a high-level opponent.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/gervonta-davis-set-return-early-2018-says-ellerbe--122460|title=Gervonta Davis Set To Return in Early 2018, Says Ellerbe - Boxing News|website=www.boxingscene.com|language=en-us|access-date=2017-11-15}}</ref> According to Mayweather Promotions CEO Leonard Ellerbe, Davis would remain at super featherweight and likely challenge for a world title in 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/ellerbe-gervonta-davis-staying-130-tabiti-back-early-2018--122940|title=Ellerbe: Gervonta Davis Staying at 130, Tabiti Back in Early 2018|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en-us}}</ref> On January 24, 2018 Showtime announced that Davis would next appear on television on the undercard of [[Adrien Broner|Broner]] vs. [[Jessie Vargas|Vargas]] on April 21 at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/broner-figueroa-stevenson-jack-lara-hurd-set-showtime--124600|title=Broner-Figueroa, Stevenson-Jack, Lara-Hurd Set For Showtime|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-01-26|language=en-us}}</ref> A day later, Ellerbe stated a deal was close to being reached for Davis to fight Australian former world champion and IBF #3 [[Billy Dib]] (43-4, 24 KOs, 2 NC) in what would be an IBF eliminator. A purse bid, which was due to take place on January 25 was postponed to February 6.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/gervonta-davis-vs-billy-dib-close-deal-purse-bid-postponed--124628|title=Gervonta Davis vs. Billy Dib - Close To Deal, Purse Bid Postponed|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-01-26|language=en-us}}</ref> On February 21, it was reported by ESPN, the fight would not happen. Instead it was stated Davis's likely opponent would be former featherweight champion [[Jesús Cuellar]] (28-2, 21 KOs). On March 5, the fight was finalized for the vacant [[List of WBA world champions#Super featherweight|WBA 'Regular']] super featherweight title.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/gervonta-davis-cuellar-my-toughest-opponent-date--125933|title=Gervonta Davis: Cuellar is My Toughest Opponent To Date|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-03-06|language=en-us}}</ref> Prior to the fight, Albert Machado, the 'Super' Champion at the same weight class, was inexplicably downgraded to "Regular' Champion, and the Davis-Cuellar fight was upgraded to be for Machado's [[list of WBA world champions#Super featherweight|WBA (Super) super featherweight title]].
In front of 13,964 in attendance, Davis knocked out Cuellar in round 3. Davis first knocked down Cuellar in round 2 courtesy of a left hook to the body and then put him down twice in round 3 to get the stoppage. Referee Benjy Esteves Jr. stopped the action at the 2:45 mark. Davis landed 49% of his power shots in the fight. Both boxers earned $350,000 apiece. After the fight, Davis stated he wanted to unify with the winner of [[Tevin Farmer]] vs. [[Billy Dib]], which would be contested for the IBF belt, the same belt Davis was stripped off.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/boxing/story/_/id/23280163/charlo-ko-centeno-becomes-one-ggg-mandatory-challengers|title=Charlo KO's Centeno, becomes one of GGG's mandatory challengers|work=ESPN.com|access-date=2018-04-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/gervonta-davis-crushes-jesus-cuellar-three-results--127417|title=Gervonta Davis Crushes Jesus Cuellar in Three For WBA Title|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-04-25|language=en-us}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.worldboxingnews.net/2018/04/22/news/gervonta-davis-drops-jesus-cuellar-three-times-regains-130-pound-world-title|title=Gervonta Davis drops Jesus Cuellar three times, regains 130 pound world title|last=Cuellar|first=Davis v|work=WBN - World Boxing News|access-date=2018-04-25|language=en-gb}}</ref> The bout opened Showtime’s broadcast and averaged 460,000 viewers and peaked at 527,000 viewers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/broner-vargas-telecast-peaked-891000-viewers-on-showtime--127498|title=Broner-Vargas Telecast Peaked at 891,000 Viewers on Showtime|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-04-25|language=en-us}}</ref>
== Outside of boxing == On September 19, 2017 an arrest warrant was issued for Davis, who was being accused of [[Assault|first-degree aggravated assault]]. According to Maryland court records, the alleged incident took place on August 1, 2017 but did not indicate who was involved or what happened. An amount of $100,000 unsecured bond was posted for Davis' release. Davis was due to appear in court on October 19.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/gervonta-davis-facing-first-degree-aggravated-assault-charge--120740|title=Gervonta Davis Facing First Degree Aggravated Assault Charge - Boxing News|website=www.boxingscene.com|language=en-us|access-date=2017-11-15}}</ref> The charge was later changed to misdemeanor second-degree assault, which carries a maximum potential sentence of 10 years or a fine of $2,500 or both. At the court, Anthony Wheeler, a childhood friend, complained that Davis punched him on the side of the head with a 'gloved fist'. He then stated he was diagnosed with a concussion in hospital. The incident took place at the Upton Boxing Center in West Baltimore. It was said that Davis would stand trial on November 29, 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/gervonta-davis-stand-trial-on-assault-charge-on-november-29--121579|title=Gervonta Davis To Stand Trial on Assault Charge on November 29 - Boxing News|website=www.boxingscene.com|language=en-us|access-date=2017-11-15}}</ref> In court, the charges were dropped by Wheeler. The [[The Baltimore Sun|Baltimore Sun]] stated that Davis and Wheeler both embraced and walked out of the courtroom together.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/gervonta-davis-all-smiles-final-assault-charge-dropped--122921|title=Gervonta Davis All Smiles as Final Assault Charge is Dropped|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en-us}}</ref>
On September 14, 2018 Davis was arrested in Washington D.C. According to a police report, he and another man started a fist fight. Punches were being landed around the upper body. It was said that some had tried to break up the fight and both men tried to flee before the police arrived.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.boxingscene.com/gervonta-davis-arrested-over-street-fight--131808|title=Gervonta Davis Arrested Over Street Fight|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-09-14|language=en-us}}</ref>

'''Hadi Norouzi''' ({{lang-fa|هادی نوروزی}}, 22 June 1985<ref>http://www.mizanonline.com/fa/news/83666/راز-شماره-24-هادی-نوروزی-عکس</ref> – 1 October 2015) was an Iranian [[association football|football]] [[Striker (association football)|striker]] who last played for [[Persepolis F.C.|Persepolis]] in the [[Iran Pro League]].<ref name="jj">[http://www.jamejamonline.ir/papertext.aspx?newsnum=100926621836 مار مي‌گيرم و با آن فرار مي‌كنم]. Jamejamonline.ir. Retrieved on 2011-11-26.</ref>
He joined [[Persepolis F.C.|Persepolis]] youth team in 2000 and was promoted to the first team squad in 2008 by [[Afshin Ghotbi]] after spend a short spell at [[Pasargad Tehran F.C.|Pasargad]] and [[Damash Iranian F.C.|Damash Iranian]]. In 2013, he joined [[Naft Tehran F.C.|Naft Tehran]] in a six-month loan contract. At the end of the season, he was returned to Persepolis and became a regular squad player.
On 1 October 2015, Norouzi died of heart attack in sleep at the age of 30.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.varzesh3.com/news/1271568/%D8%A8%D8%A7%D9%88%D8%B1%D9%86%DA%A9%D8%B1%D8%AF%D9%86%DB%8C-%DA%A9%D8%A7%D9%BE%DB%8C%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86-%D9%85%D8%AA%D8%B9%D8%B5%D8%A8-%D9%BE%D8%B1%D8%B3%D9%BE%D9%88%D9%84%DB%8C%D8%B3-%D8%AF%D8%B1%DA%AF%D8%B0%D8%B4%D8%AA|title=باورنکردنی: کاپیتان متعصب پرسپولیس درگذشت|work=ورزش سه|accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref> At the time of his death, he was Persepolis' captain, having been named as the club captain two months before.
==Club career==
===Early years=== Norouzi joined [[Persepolis F.C.|Persepolis]] in summer 2000 from [[Persepolis F.C. Academy|Persepolis U19]]. He played four seasons for [[Persepolis F.C. Academy|Persepolis U19]] and moved to [[Pasargad Tehran F.C.|Pasargad]]. He moved back to [[Persepolis F.C. Academy|Persepolis U21]] after he served his conscription in [[Fajr Sepah Tehran]]. He left [[Persepolis F.C. Academy|Persepolis U21]] teams for [[Damash Iranian F.C.|Damah Iranian]]'s Senior team of [[Azadegan League|Division 1]].
===Persepolis=== Next year he returned to Persepolis, where he was mostly used as a substitute in [[2008–09 Persian Gulf Cup|2008–09 season]]. He was top assistant of [[Persepolis F.C.|Persepolis]] in [[2010–11 Persepolis F.C. season|2010–11 season]], and extended his contract with [[Persepolis F.C.|Persepolis]] another two-years in summer 2013, keeping him in the team until 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.perspolisnews.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=46694:2013-05-27-13-24-06&catid=45&Itemid=848|title=نوروزی با پرسپولیس به توافق رسید/مشکل سرخ‌ها با انصاری‌فرد سر دو بند قرارداد – Perspolisnews.Com|author=ali-rad|work=perspolisnews.com|accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref>
===Loan to Naft Tehran=== He joined [[Naft Tehran]] with a season-long loan as November 26, 2013.<ref>[http://fc-perspolis.com/news_content/main/newsId:16287 Hadi Norouzi loaned to Naft Tehran]</ref> He made 12 appearances for Naft and scored three goals.
===Return to Persepolis=== Norouzi returned to Persepolis before the start of [[2014–15 Persepolis F.C. season|2014–15]] season after spending six months at [[Naft Tehran]]. He was named captain of the club before the start of the 2015–16 season after former captain [[Mohammad Nouri (footballer)|Mohammad Nouri]] left the club.

==International career== He started his International Career under [[Afshin Ghotbi]] in August 2009 against [[Bosnia and Herzegovina national football team|Bosnia and Herzegovina]]. He played nine international cups.
==Death and tributes== {{refimprove section|date=October 2015}} [[File:Persepolis first training after the death of Norouzi 06.jpg|thumb|Persepolis players in the first training after Norouzi's death]] In the morning of 1 October 2015, Persepolis team manager [[Mahmoud Khordbin]] announced that the club captain Hadi Norouzi died in his sleep from a heart attack due to [[hypertrophic cardiomyopathy]]. Resuscitation attempts on the way to the hospital failed. Norouzi was 30.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.persianleague.com/the-news/1-latest-news/9796-persepolis-captain-hadi-norouzi-passes-away.html|title=PERSEPOLIS CAPTAIN HADI NOROUZI PASSES AWAY|work=persianleague.com|accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref> Persepolis manager [[Branko Ivanković]] describes the news as a big shock for him and his team. Persepolis players and legends like [[Ali Parvin]], [[Ahmad Reza Abedzadeh]], [[Karim Bagheri]] and former managers [[Afshin Ghotbi]] and [[Ali Daei]] paid tributes to Norouzi and his family in their messages. [[Iran Pro League]] clubs also paid tributes to Persepolis club and fans in [[Twitter]]. [[Iran national football team]] players observed a [[minute's silence]] for Norouzi at their training camp in United Arab Emirates. Many fans also immediately flocked to Persepolis' training ground, [[Derafshifar Stadium]] where he had participated in a training session in last day without any problem, to lay flowers and light candles.
A memorial was held at [[Azadi Stadium]] on 2 October which was attended by 20,000 mourners which rivals [[Esteghlal F.C.|Esteghlal]] fans also attended the ceremony. His body remained at the stadium for one day and then was transferred to [[Babol]]. His funeral was held on the following day and he was buried at his hometown, [[Kapur Chal, Mazandaran|Kapur Chal]] village at [[Babol]].
On 4 October 2015, former teammate [[Karim Ansarifard]] dedicated his goal in his team's 5–1 [[Greek Super League]] win to him, by raising a shirt with his name and number (#24, REST IN PEACE CAPTAIN). [[Iran national under-23 football team]] players also dedicated their win to Hadi Norouzi during their match against [[Bahrain national under-23 football team|Bahrain]] at [[2015 WAFF U-23 Championship]].
In Persepolis' first match after the death of Norouzi, fans cheered-up him in 24th minute. They also made a mosaique at the stadium which shows Norouzi's name and number, "Hadi 24". Persepolis and his native city's club [[Khoneh Be Khoneh Mazandaran F.C.|Khoneh Be Khoneh]] retired their number 24 shirt in his honour. A city square was also renamed to Hadi Norouzi square in his home town [[Babol]].
==Personal life== [[File:Fars interview with family of Hadi Norouzi (13941213142403177).jpg|thumb|Noroozi's spouse Masoumeh Ebrahimpour and their two children, 8 March 2016.]] Norouzi had four siblings, all brothers and he was the youngest son of his family. He was married to Masoumeh Ebrahimpour in 2003.<ref>[http://saten.ir/85409/%D8%A7%D8%AA%D9%81%D8%A7%D9%82%DB%8C-%D8%AA%D9%84%D8%AE%DB%8C-%DA%A9%D9%87-%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%B5%D9%88%D9%85%D9%87-%D8%A7%D8%A8%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%87%DB%8C%D9%85-%D9%BE%D9%88%D8%B1-%D8%8C%D9%87%D9%85%D8%B3/ Interview with Masoumeh Ebrahimpour, widow of Hadi Norouzi]</ref> The couple had two children, a boy Hani (born 2009)<ref>[http://saten.ir/85052/%D9%81%D8%B1%D8%B2%D9%86%D8%AF%D8%A7%D9%86-%D9%87%D8%A7%D8%AF%DB%8C-%D9%86%D9%88%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%B2%DB%8C-%D9%BE%D8%B3-%D8%A7%D8%B2-%D9%81%D9%88%D8%AA-%D9%BE%D8%AF%D8%B1-%D8%B9%DA%A9%D8%B3/ Hadi Norouzi's son after his death]</ref> and a girl, Hana (born 2014).

'''K-Mix 2''' is a high energy food, used for the treatment of severe [[malnutrition]].<ref name="sfp">{{cite book|title=Selective Feeding Programmes Volume 1|year=1984|page=86|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nxvnBWHWsX4C&pg=PA86&lpg=PA86&dq=k-mix+unicef&source=bl&ots=vou0Gf3QYE&sig=2HufebIH9ItMJQ0AZEYkaVuWuEE&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MEIqUdWIEtSEhQfij4DgBw&ved=0CEkQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=k-mix%20unicef&f=false|author=Tim Lusty, Pat Diskett|accessdate=24 February 2013}}</ref> It was developed by [[UNICEF]] in response to the [[Nigerian Civil War|Biafran War]],<ref name=hist>{{cite web|title=History of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund|url=http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/united-nations-international-children-s-emergency-fund-unicef-history/|publisher=Funding Universe|accessdate=24 February 2013}}</ref> and was widely used in later famines in India and Africa.
It is a dry mix of : 3 parts by weight [[Calcium caseinate]] : 5 parts Dried Skimmed Milk : 10 parts sugar When made up, the 100g K-Mix-2 is combined with 60g of oil and 1 litre of water<ref name="sfp" />
Although extremely effective in the treatment of children too weak to feed themselves,<ref name="hist" /> its high cost precludes it from being used in any but the most extreme cases, and after the acute malnutrition has been treated, other foods are used instead<ref>{{cite book|title=Food and Nutrition in the Management of Group Feeding Programmes|year=1993|publisher=Food & Agriculture Org|page=23|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h0PaO47cMDUC&pg=PA23&lpg=PA23&dq=k-mix+unicef&source=bl&ots=aZoi2DqQXM&sig=6PiThIq_g5bI2CBDB-hy7wjPF9w&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HEcqUYPSBMrJ0QWBpIG4Bw&ved=0CHYQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=k-mix%20unicef&f=false|edition=23}}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox dancer | name = Malanga | image = | alt = | caption = | full_name = | birth_name = José Rosario Oviedo | birth_date = {{birth date|1885|10|5 |mf=yes}} | birth_place = Alacranes, [[Unión de Reyes]], [[Matanzas Province|Matanzas]], [[Cuba]] | death_date = {{Death year and age|1927|1885|}} | death_place = [[Morón, Cuba|Morón]] | height = | occupation = [[Cuban rumba]] dancer | years_active = | current_group = | former_groups = | dances = | website = }} '''José Rosario Oviedo''' (October 5, 1885{{spaced ndash}}1927), better known as '''Malanga''', was a Cuban [[Cuban rumba|rumba]] dancer. He is considered one of the most famous [[Cuban rumba#Columbia|columbia]] dancers and his mysterious death has been the subject of numerous essays, poems and songs, most notably "Malanga murió", written by Faustino Drake and performed by [[Arsenio Rodríguez]] amongst others.
== Life and career ==
===Early life=== José Rosario Oviedo was born on October 5, 1885 in "La Esperanza", an [[Engenho|ingenio]] near the village of Alacranes in the [[Unión de Reyes]] municipality, [[Matanzas Province]], [[Cuba]].<ref name="Roy">{{cite book|last1=Roy|first1=Maya|title=Músicas cubanas|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ylUYYWXumY8C|date=2003|publisher=Akal|location=Tres Cantos, Spain|page=59|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref name="Ecured">[http://www.ecured.cu/index.php/Jos%C3%A9_Rosario_Oviedo José Rosario Oviedo "Malanga"]. ''[[EcuRed]]'' (in Spanish). Retrieved June 23, 2015.</ref>{{refn|group=nb|In the past, some researchers believed he had been born in Sabanilla del Encomendador, a nearby village now known as Juan Gualberto Gómez. However, this has been shown to be false.<ref name="Doc">Interview with Unión de Reyes historian Henry García. ''[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BoDdBE1Z_3U Rumba cubana]''. Retrieved June 23, 2015.</ref>}} He was [[Infant baptism|baptisted]] on November 29 as the son of an "unknown father".<ref name="Ecured" /> His mother, Funciana Oviedo, was an ex-slave and raised him in the town of Unión de Reyes after living in several ingenios such as "Majagua" and "San Gonzalo".<ref name="Ecured" /><ref name="Fire">{{cite book|last1=Leymarie|first1=Isabel|title=Cuban Fire: Musiques populaires d'expression cubaine|date=1997|publisher=Outre Mesure|location=Paris, France|page=29|language=French}}</ref> His godmother Saturnina Oviedo and his grandfather (also his godfather) José Quintero played an important role in his upbringing.<ref name="Ecured" /> Despite being christened in the [[Catholic]] faith, Malanga became a [[Santería]] practitioner; his [[orisha]] was [[Oshosi|Ochosí]].<ref name="Doc" /> He soon became a talented rumba dancer, performing with a group which featured Ángel Timbo, Ángel Calazán, Faustino Drake and Donato Torres.<ref name="Ecured" /> The percussionists played [[cajón|cajones]], wooden boxes that preceded the [[conga drum]].
===Style and professional career=== Malanga's style of dancing was unlike that of his contemporaries. He danced on his tiptoes, like [[ballet]] dancers, and often danced "on top of a dining room table with a glass of water on his head, making all the movements of the dance or picking up a handkerchief off the floor without spilling the water".<ref>Vázquez, Omar (2000). "Malanga, el timbero mayor". ''Salsa Cubana'' 4:11.</ref> <ref name="sublette">{{cite book|last1=Sublette|first1=Ned|title=Cuba and its Music: From the First Drums to the Mambo|date=2004|publisher=Chicago Review Press|location=Chicago, IL|pages=269–270|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fZZ4QKZEumIC}}</ref> According to famous [[tres (instrument)|tres]] player [[Isaac Oviedo]], "he moved blindfolded with a glass of water on his head (...) without ever losing his step or the rhythm".<ref name="sublette" />
Apart from being a dancer, Malanga worked as a representative for the [[Liberal Party of Cuba|Partido Liberal]] in Unión de Reyes, and as a [[sugar cane]] cutter, especially in the 1910s and 1920s, when work opportunities decreased in the region. During the ''[[Zafra (agriculture)|zafra]]'' season he had to migrate to the "sugar triangle" towns of [[Florida, Cuba|Florida]], [[Morón, Cuba|Morón]] and [[Ciego de Ávila]].<ref name="Roy" /><ref name="Ecured" />
===Death=== In the summer of 1927, when returning alone from Morón, Malanga died in unexplained circumstances.{{refn|group=nb|He is often incorrectly said to have died in 1923, a year cited from Helio Orovio's 1994 work ''Música por el Caribe''.<ref name="Roy" />}} The most popular account of Malanga's death has been given by Crescencio Hernández "Chencho", according to whom Malanga was murdered with broken glass hidden in his food at a dance contest in Ceballos, near Morón.<ref name="Ecured" /><ref name="Doc" /> However, this ''modus operandi'' has generally been debunked.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mikkelson|first1=Barbara|title=Pain in the Glass|url=http://www.snopes.com/horrors/poison/glass.asp|website=Snopes|accessdate=June 23, 2015|date=June 12, 2014}}</ref> No death certificate had been found,<ref name="Ecured" /> and the location of his grave remains unknown.<ref name="montuno">{{cite web|last1=Dalmace|first1=Patrick|title=Malanga|url=http://www.montunocubano.com/Tumbao/biographies/malanga.htm|website=Montuno Cubano|accessdate=June 23, 2015|language=French}}</ref>
== In popular culture == Together with others such as Mulense, Chenche and Tanganica, Malanga is one of Cuba's "legendary ''rumberos''", being remembered as one of the most notable rumba dancers, especially in the columbia style.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shepherd|first1=John|last2=Horn|first2=David|title=Bloomsbury Encyclopedia of Popular Music of the World, Volume 9|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=liV8AwAAQBAJ|date=2014|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|location=London, UK|page=719|chapter=Rumba}}</ref> As a result, his life and especially his death have been the subject of many works, from essays to poems and songs. Cuban poet Fernando García González wrote a poem in 1985 dedicated to Malanga entitled "Canto al Rumbero Mayor".<ref name="Ecured" />
Cajón de quinto drummer Faustino Drake, one of Malanga's dearest friends, composed the song "Malanga murió", also known as "A Malanga" in 1927 as an [[elegy]]. It is one of the most popular [[guaguancó]]s and its tone is remarkably solemn, as summarized by its well-known chorus: "Unión de Reyes llora / porque Malanga murió" (Unión de Reyes cries / because Malanga died). The song was originally sung by Roncona and later recorded by [[Arsenio Rodríguez]] as "[[Arsenio Rodríguez discography|Llora timbero]]" in 1941.<ref name="Garcia">{{cite book|last1=García|first1=David|title=Arsenio Rodríguez and the Transnational Flows of Latin Popular Music|date=2006|publisher=Temple University Press|location=Philadelphia, PA|pages=147–166|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4e5GF9NwHucC|chapter=Discography}}</ref>

[[File:Marie-Louise Bruyère.jpg|thumb|right|Marie-Louise Bruyère in 1950]] '''Marie-Louise Bruyère''', mostly known as '''Madame Bruyère''', or simply as '''Bruyère''' (pronounced Broo-yair),<ref name=butterick>{{cite book|title=Butterick dressmaking book|year=1940|publisher=Butterick Company|pages=90|url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=twGUUJDEOceN0wXC-oGIBQ&sqi=2&id=hExEAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22Madame+Bruyere%22&q=%22Madame+Bruyere%22#search_anchor}}</ref> was a French fashion designer of the 1930s, 1940s and 1950s, operating out of [[Paris]], and importing her fashion lines abroad.
==Fashion career== Before Bruyère opened her [[haute couture]] house in 1928, she learned her trade from [[Callot Soeurs]] and [[Jeanne Lanvin]].<ref name=kyoto>{{cite book|last=Fukai|first=Akiko|title=Fashion : the collection of the Kyoto Costume Institute: a history from the 18th to the 20th century| year=2002 |publisher=Taschen |location=Köln [etc.] |isbn=3822812064 |pages=713}}</ref> Her establishment was located on the [[Place Vendôme]] in Paris.<ref>''International Pattern'', [[Los Angeles Times]], December 30, 1954, pg. B4.</ref> An early collection in 1930 established Bruyère as comparable to [[Elsa Schiaparelli|Schiaparelli]], [[Grès|Alix]], [[Rochas]] and [[Mainbocher]],<ref name=butterick/> with her coats and tailored suits proving a particular strength. Her suits were particularly noted for their subtle and unusual design elements.<ref name=nyt/> In August 1932 ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' noted that her designs were rather more successful with Americans than with the French, who did not visit Bruyère's shop on the Rue de Mondovi.<ref name=fortune>{{cite news|last1=Staff writer |title=The Dressmakers of France |url=http://www.gbacg.org/costume-resources/original/articles/dressmakers.pdf |accessdate=19 November 2015 |work=Fortune |publisher=Time, Inc |date=August 1932}}</ref> Bruyère's designs were imported to the United States,<ref name=nyt>''Fine Touches Make the Beauty of Newest Models Imported From Paris'', [[New York Times]], January 1, 1933, pg. X11.</ref> and in 1932, ''Fortune'' noted that a survey of copies of Paris couture gowns in the stores of [[Manhattan]] showed that Bruyère was the third most popular name, behind [[Madeleine Vionnet|Vionnet]] and Lanvin.<ref name=fortune/>
Bruyère continued to present collections during the [[German occupation of France during World War II|German occupation]], now taking into account the needs of Frenchwomen who needed practical clothing that could handle the bitter winters and harsh realities of life while occupied.<ref>''Fashion under the occupation'', Dominique Veillon, [[Berg Publishers]], 2002, pg. 34.</ref>
After the war ended, Bruyère was not a supporter of the full-skirted New Look as popularised by [[Christian Dior]], instead offering extremely simple, slim-line dresses and suits with plunging necklines in 1951.<ref name=toomey>{{cite news |last1=Toomey |first1=Elizabeth |title=Parisian Styles Come To America With Fall Show. |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1817&dat=19510808&id=PPs-AAAAIBAJ&sjid=TU0MAAAAIBAJ&pg=5826,2963504 |accessdate=12 December 2014 |work=The Tuscaloosa News |date=8 August 1951}}</ref>
In the 1950s, Bruyère began to focus on [[ready-to-wear]] clothing.<ref name=vfg>{{cite web |last=Bramlett |first=Lizzie |title=Vintage Fashion Guild: Label Reference: Bruyere |url=http://vintagefashionguild.org/label-resource/bruyere/ |accessdate=2 November 2012}}</ref> She came to an agreement in 1951 with the Baron-Peters dress firm in the United States to reproduce her designs for the American medium-priced ready-to-wear market, carefully emphasising that the designs were pure replicas of her Paris collection, and not "whipped up for American tastes."<ref name=toomey2>{{cite news |last1=Toomey |first1=Elizabeth |title=Paris Springs Another Label in America|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1999943/el_paso_heraldpost/ |accessdate=16 March 2015 |work=El Paso Herald-Post |agency=United Press |date= 22 August 1951 |via=[[Newspapers.com]]}}</ref> In 1952 it was noted that most of Bruyère's business came from American clients.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bergmann |first1=Shirley |title=What Goes on Behind the Doors of a Leading Fashion House |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1999812/freeport_journalstandard/ |accessdate=16 March 2015 |work=Freeport Journal-Standard |date=7 August 1952 |via=[[Newspapers.com]]}}</ref>
In 1958 Bruyère was noted alongside a number of other female Parisian fashion designers, her designs described as flowing and ladylike, and worn by many famous actresses and socialites.<ref name=iris>{{cite news |last1=Hartman |first1=Iris |title=Women Lead in Creation of Fashions |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=953&dat=19580302&id=QPZPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=X1UDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5752,268536|accessdate=12 December 2014|work=St Petersburg Independent|date=2 March 1958}}</ref> She is thought to have ceased business during the 1950s.<ref name=kyoto/><ref name=vfg/>

{{Infobox book | name = Misty of Chincoteague | title_orig = | translator = | image = Misty of Chincoteague cover.jpg | caption= First edition | author = [[Marguerite Henry]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | series = | subject = | genre = [[Children's novel]], [[pony book]] | publisher = [[Rand McNally]] | pub_date = 1947 | media_type = | pages = 173 pp. (first ed.) | isbn = | oclc = 176811 | congress = PZ10.3.H43 Mg[http://lccn.loc.gov/47011404 "Misty of Chincoteague"] (first edition). Library of Congress Online Catalog. Retrieved 2015-02-16. | preceded_by = | followed_by = "Sea Star: Orphan of Chincoteague" (1949)
"[[Stormy, Misty's Foal]]" (1963)
"Misty's Twilight" (1992) }} '''''Misty of Chincoteague''''' is a children's novel written by [[Marguerite Henry]], illustrated by [[Wesley Dennis (illustrator)|Wesley Dennis]], and published by Rand McNally in 1947. Set in the island town of [[Chincoteague, Virginia]], the book tells the story of the Beebe family and their efforts to raise a filly born to a wild horse. It was one of the runners-up for the annual [[Newbery Medal]], now called Newbery Honor Books.{{cite web|url=http://ala.org/ala/mgrps/divs/alsc/awardsgrants/bookmedia/newberymedal/newberyhonors/newberymedal.cfm|title=Newbery Medal and Honor Books, 1922-Present|first=|last=admin|date=30 November 1999|publisher=|accessdate=21 October 2016}} The 1961 film ''[[Misty (film)|Misty]]'' was based on the book.[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0055186/ ''Misty'' at the Internet Movie Database]. ==Plot== ''Misty of Chincoteague'' begins with an account of the wreck of a [[Spanish galleon]] on the shores of [[Assateague Island]] off the coast of Virginia. The ponies in the hold of the galleon swim to Assateague and become feral as the years and eventually the centuries pass. The book then tells the story of two orphan children, Paul and Maureen Beebe, who move in with their grandparents after their parents die.{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1997-12-28/features/1997362169_1_misty-of-chincoteague-pony-paul-and-maureen|title='Misty of Chincoteague' tale gallops on Horse: Marguerite Henry, who died recently, wrote 59 books, but her tale of two orphans and a horse remains a breed apart.|publisher=|accessdate=21 October 2016}} Paul and Maureen work to earn money to buy a Chincoteague pony [[mare]] named the Phantom, who has escaped the roundup men on Pony Penning Day for the past two years. Paul and Maureen save enough to buy Phantom, and Paul is able to capture her on the roundup because she is slowed down by her new foal, Misty. However, a man from the mainland buys the pair of ponies for his son before Paul and Maureen can give their money to the fire chief. Paul and Maureen are distressed, but they end up being able to buy Phantom and Misty because the original buyer's son won a colt in the yearly raffle and then decided he didn't need another pony, and chose the colt from the raffle. Paul and Maureen eventually break the Phantom to ride, and the next year Paul races her on Pony Penning Day. Phantom wins, but the next day becomes distressed when she sees the herd she once belonged to, led by a [[stallion]] called Pied Piper, being released to swim back to Assateague. Paul releases Phantom, and she gallops to join Pied Piper and the herd as they return to freedom on their ancestral island. Misty remains behind with Paul and Maureen. ==Inspiration for novel== ''Misty'' was inspired by a real-life [[Chincoteague Pony]] by the same name. The real-life Misty was foaled in domesticity in 1946, on Chincoteague at the [[Beebe Ranch]], not in the wild on [[Assateague Island]] as told in the book. As in the book, however, she was in fact sired by a chestnut pinto [[stallion]] named Pied Piper, from a smokey-black pinto [[Mare|dam]] called Phantom. Although these horses also were domesticated in real life, they too provided inspiration to Henry for the [[feral horse|wild ponies]] portrayed in the novel. Misty was a chestnut and white [[pinto horse|pinto]], whose coloration and markings included a large patch of white on her side shaped much like the United States. Her hoof prints are impressed in the cement of the sidewalk outside the Roxy Movie Theatre in Chincoteague.{{cite web|url=http://www.chincoteaguechamber.com/i-roxy-theatre.html|title=Island Theatre - Chincoteague Chamber|publisher=|accessdate=21 October 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100414101950/http://www.chincoteaguechamber.com/i-roxy-theatre.html|archivedate=14 April 2010|df=}} After being purchased by Marguerite Henry as a [[weanling]] in November 1946, and spending her early life at Henry's [[Wayne, Illinois]] home, she was later moved back to the Beebe Ranch in Chincoteague in 1957.[http://www.mistysheaven.com/historyofmisty.html "History of Misty of Chincoteague", ''Misty's Heaven'' - Misty'sHeaven.com] Retrieved 2015-08-07 A goodbye party with over 300 children and 160 adults in attendance was held by Henry in Wayne for Misty when she left for Chincoteague. Back in Chincoteague, Misty had three foals: "Phantom Wings" in 1960, "Wisp O' Mist" in 1961, and "[[Stormy, Misty's Foal|Stormy]]", a chestnut pinto [[filly]] with a [[Horse markings|blaze]] in the shape of a crescent moon on her forehead, in 1962. As of 2015, there were almost 200 known descendants of Misty.{{cite web|url=http://mistysheaven.com|title=Misty's Heaven: Descendants of Misty of Chincoteague|accessdate=2015-07-27}} Paul Beebe died in a car accident in 1957 at the age of 21. Clarence Beebe died two months later in 1957 after Paul's accident. Three years later Ida Beebe died in 1960.{{cite web|url=http://articles.dailypress.com/1989-07-26/news/8907260145_1_grandma-beebe-misty-pony|title=Era Draws To Close At Home Of `Misty'|publisher=|accessdate=21 October 2016}} Misty died in 1972. Her body, and that of her foal Stormy who died in 1993, have been preserved through [[taxidermy]], and can be seen at the [[Beebe Ranch]].[http://www.delmarvanow.com/dayinthelife/chincoteague/pages/chincoteaguestory7.html Chincoteague story][http://www.roadsideamerica.com/pet/misty.html Misty profile] at roadsideamerica.com The Misty of Chincoteague Foundation was formed by Marguerite Henry and Rebecca Guisti in 1990, with the two-fold mission of preserving Misty's legacy, and promoting reading by children. Funds were raised to commission a statue of Misty, sculpted by Brian Maughan, to be erected on Chincoteague, which was formally unveiled on July 29, 1997. An identical casting of the Maughan statue was also placed at [[Kentucky Horse Park]] in [[Lexington, KY|Lexington, Kentucky]]. == Marguerite Henry's "Misty" series == [[File:Marguerite Henry.jpg|thumb| [[Marguerite Henry]] with Misty]] * ''Misty of Chincoteague'', illustrated by Wesley Dennis (1947) * ''Sea Star: Orphan of Chincoteague'', illus. Wesley Dennis (Rand McNally, 1949), sequel novel, {{OCLC|4669796}} * ''Misty, the Wonder Pony, by Misty, Herself'', illus. Clare McKinley (1956), picture book * ''[[Stormy, Misty's Foal]]'' (1963), illus. Wesley Dennis, sequel novel * ''A Pictorial Life Story of Misty'', drawings by Wesley Dennis (Rand McNally, 1976), {{OCLC|2423734}} * ''Misty's Twilight'', illus. Karen Haus Grandpré (Macmillan, 1992) – "Captivated by the story of ''Misty of Chincoteague'', a woman with a horse farm in Florida raises one of Misty's descendants to become a champion show horse", {{OCLC|25007971}} In the second novel, ''Sea Star'', published only two years after the original, Misty is "sold to be shared with children the country over" and the Beebe children rescue a "tiny orphaned colt" after the Pony Penning.[https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/marguerite-henry/mistys-twilight/ "Sea Star: Orphan of Chincoteague"] (starred review). ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]''. No date. Retrieved 2015-02-14. The third novel, ''Stormy, Misty's Foal'', was published in 1963. It tells of the Ash Wednesday Storm of 1962 on Chincoteague, and the birth of Misty's last foal Stormy. Misty and Stormy had made appearances at theaters and schools in the area to help raise funds for replenishment of the herds on Assateague in the aftermath of the 1962 storm. The fourth novel, ''Misty's Twilight'', was published after Henry's 90th birthday, and almost 30 years after the third. ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]'' observed that it was "billed as fiction but more like a fictionalization concerning one of Misty's descendants". It concluded its contemporary review, "this adult-centered narrative about an affluent doctor—whose troubles with her horse are always addressed by hiring yet another trainer—may be authentic, it will be of interest mostly to those who relish every crumb about Misty's family."[https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/marguerite-henry/mistys-twilight/ Misty's Twilight"]. ''Kirkus Reviews''. June 15, 1992. Retrieved 2015-02-14. ==50th anniversary release== For the 50th anniversary in 1997 of the original novel, only the month before Henry's death, Simon & Schuster released a diary garnished with quotations from ''Misty of Chincoteague'' and new illustrations by Bill Farnsworth (Little Simon, October 1997); {{ISBN|9780689817694}}. ==Misty's legacy in other literature== Several of the real-life Misty's descendants have been featured in books by other authors, in addition to Henry: * ''Windy of Chincoteague'' by Ronald Keiper (1987) — small non-fiction book about Misty's first granddaughter Windy. * ''Pony Promise'' by Lois Szymanski (1996) — fiction, but based on the true story of Windy nursing her half-sister Misty II along with her own foal Cyclone, because of Stormy rejecting Misty II. * ''Nightmist the Miracle Pony'' by Jessie-Ann Friend (2005) — children's book about Misty's great-grandson Nightmist. * ''The Forgotten Pony'' by Jessie Ann-Friend (2007) — children's book about Misty's great-grandson, Rainy's Boy. A series of children's books by Misty family pony-breeder Kendy Allen debuted in 2006. The series includes: * ''Misty's Heart of the Storm'' * ''Misty's Black Mist and the Christmas Parade'' * ''A Chincoteague Pony Named Misty III'' * ''Ember's Story, The Misty Miracle Pony'' == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{Portal |Children's literature}} {{commons category|Misty of Chincoteague}} * [http://www.chincoteague.com Chincoteague Homepage] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100415115152/http://www.chincoteaguechamber.com/map-assn.html Chincoteague Pony Association] * [http://www-pub.naz.edu:9000/~csick4/misty.html Horse Tails: Misty of Chincoteague] * [http://www.mistysheaven.com Misty's Heaven] * [http://www.mistysheaven.com/historyofmisty.html The History of Misty] * [http://www.thehiddengalleon.com More on the Beebe Family and the legendary Spanish galleon] * [http://www.mistyofchincoteague.org The Misty of Chincoteague Foundation preserves the legacy of Marguerite Henry] * {{Find a Grave|10497703|Misty of Chincoteague}} * {{Find a Grave|151252914|Stormy of Chincoteague}} * {{Find a Grave|10900080|Ida Whealton Beebe}} * {{Find a Grave|10900041|Clarence Beebe}} * {{Find a Grave|10874957|Paul Beebe}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Misty Of Chincoteague}} [[Category:1947 American novels]] [[Category:Newbery Honor-winning works]] [[Category:Novels by Marguerite Henry]] [[Category:Novels set in Virginia]] [[Category:Ponies]] [[Category:1946 animal births]] [[Category:1972 animal deaths]] [[Category:Chincoteague, Virginia]] [[Category:Novels set on islands]] [[Category:Novels about horses]] [[Category:Children's novels about animals]] [[Category:American novels adapted into films]] [[Category:American children's novels]] [[Category:1947 children's books]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox person |name=Barbara Barnes |image=File:Barnes, Barbara.jpg |image_caption= School portrait of Barbara Barnes |birth_name= Barbara Ann Barnes |birth_date={{birth date|1982|08|12}} |birth_place=[[Steubenville]], Ohio, US |disappeared_date={{Death-date and age| December 7, 1995 | August 8, 1982}} |disappeared_place=Steubenville, Ohio, US |body_discovered= February 22, 1996 |death_cause= [[Homicide]] by [[strangulation]] |nationality= American |occupation= Student |known_for= Murder victim }}
'''Barbara Ann Barnes''' was an [[Americans|American]] schoolgirl who was murdered in December 1995 at the age of thirteen. The case remains [[cold case|unsolved]] to this day. Many have speculated that her grandfather may have been responsible for her death, but others believe that the crime was committed by someone local to the area.<ref name=who>{{cite book|last=Swaint|first=Jack|title=Who killed--? Pittsburgh, PA|date=July 10, 2007|publisher=Rooftop Pub.|location=Bloomington, IN|isbn=1600080405|url=https://books.google.com/?id=c4pUohXVD9oC&pg=PA21&lpg=PA21&dq=barbara+barnes+murdered#v=onepage&q=barbara%20barnes%20murdered|accessdate=May 20, 2014|chapter=Who Killed 13-Year-Old Barbara Ann Barnes?}}</ref> Journalist [[James Renner]] has published his theory that the case may be connected to the murders of [[Murder of Tina Harmon|Tina Harmon]], [[murder of Krista Harrison|Krista Harrison]], Deborah Smith and [[Amy Mihaljevic]].<ref name=Disciple>{{cite web|last=Renner, James|title=The Serial Killer's Desciple|url=http://www.johndouglasmindhunter.com/forums/viewtopic.php?p=40041&sid=a7a01169ea64b76894c0bcf186e95a27|accessdate=May 22, 2012}}{{dead link|date=December 2017}}</ref>
==Background== Barnes was described as having been a soft-spoken girl who did well in school. She was in eighth grade and attended the nearby Harding Middle School. Because of the short distance between her home and her school, she walked to and from it every day, along with many other students.<ref name=who/> Her father had been shot to death in 1989, which had affected her to the point where her personality had changed.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Goddard|first1=Alexandria|title=Who Killed Barbara?|url=http://prinniefied.com/wp/2012/05/13/who-killed-barbara/|accessdate=January 18, 2015}}</ref>
==Disappearance and murder==
It was reported by a classmate that Barnes was walking to [[school]] in her hometown of [[Steubenville, Ohio]] when she was [[kidnapping|abducted]] on December 7, 1995. After she failed to return home, an investigation began, including statewide searches.<ref name=wells>{{cite web|last=Connors|first=Fred|title=All Cases Summary|url=http://ovcoldcasessummary.blogspot.com/|accessdate=May 20, 2014|date=June 11, 2011}}</ref> On February 22, 1996, her remains were discovered by [[quantity surveyor|surveyors]] in a riverbed and the cause of death was determined by examiners to have been by [[strangulation]] and she had also been raped.<ref name=who/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Swaint|first1=Jack|title=Unsolved Murders In The Mountain State|url=http://westvirginianews.blogspot.com/2009/09/unsolved-murder-in-mountain-state.html|website=westvirginianews.blogspot.com|accessdate=January 18, 2015}}</ref>
==Investigation==
Although her body was discovered on the property of her uncle, Louis Boyce, he was not charged with her murder. Boyce has remained under suspicion due to the fact that he reportedly did not pass a [[polygraph]] test regarding the murder of Barbara. He is also believed by Barnes' family as well as members of the city to have been partially responsible for the murder of Barbara's father, although one man is currently serving life in prison for his death.<ref name=who/>
A friend of Boyce expressed that it was unlikely that her grandfather had anything to do with the murder, stating that it was not likely for him to have harmed any of his grandchildren. Other leads include a Florida man convicted of abducting children who had been present in Steubenville when Barbara Barnes was abducted, although some members of the police department are skeptical, supporting the theory that she may have been murdered by someone native to the area.<ref name=who/><ref name=wells/>

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Destiny Norton | birth_name = Destiny Anne Norton | birth_date = {{Birth date|2000|11|30}} | birth_place = | death_date = July 16, 2006 (age 5) | death_place = [[Salt Lake City|Salt Lake City, Utah]] | nationality = [[Americans|American]] | mother = Rachael Norton | father = Ricky Norton }}
'''Destiny Anne Norton''' (November 30, 2000 – July 16, 2006)<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.foundagrave.com/grave/destiny-norton/|title=Destiny Norton - Found a Grave|work=Found a Grave|access-date=August 25, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref> was a victim of [[kidnap]]ping and [[murder]].
==Murder== Until her death, she lived in [[Salt Lake City|Salt Lake City, Utah]]. On July 16, 2006, she disappeared from her home. Her body was found fewer than 100 feet from her home in the basement of her neighbor, 20-year-old Craig Roger Gregerson.
She was last seen as she left her home after arguing with her parents about going to bed. She lived in a small ranch house with her parents, and about ten other couples and friends who shared the house for economic reasons.
Volunteers posted missing posters throughout Salt Lake City, describing her several silver capped teeth on the bottom row of her mouth, blonde hair and green eyes, and dressed in a grey shirt with black stripes.
==Investigation== After a massive eight-day search by about 5,000 community volunteers, FBI and police, Destiny's body was found on July 24, 2006, less than 100 feet from her home in the basement of her neighbor, 20-year-old Craig Roger Gregerson.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ksl.com/?nid=148&sid=380101|title=Destiny Norton Found Dead, Suspect Arrested|date=July 25, 2006|publisher=KSL.com|accessdate=August 5, 2018}}</ref> Family and friends were initially outraged after the search ended, and accused authorities of mishandling the investigation. An apology on behalf of the family and friends was later issued in a press conference.
==Aftermath== Gregerson was formally charged on July 27, 2006 with kidnapping and aggravated murder. He waived his rights to a [[speedy trial]], and later waived his rights to a preliminary hearing which had originally been scheduled for October 3 and 4, 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kutv.com/local/local_story_219121551.html |title= October Preliminary Hearing Set For Gregerson|publisher=kutv.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070312104342/http://kutv.com/local/local_story_219121551.html|archivedate=March 12, 2007|date=August 7, 2006|accessdate=August 5, 2018}}</ref> In a plea bargain to avoid the death penalty, he pleaded guilty to capital murder and child kidnapping on December 4, and was sentenced to life in prison without parole for the murder, and fifteen years to life for the kidnapping. The sentences will be served consecutively.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.deseretnews.com/article/650212485/Gregerson-pleads-guilty-gets-life-for-killing-Destiny.html|title=Gregerson pleads guilty, gets life for killing Destiny|date=December 5, 2006|publisher=Desert News|author=Ben Winslow |accessdate=August 5, 2018}}</ref>
In 2007, the Destiny Search Project<ref>{{cite web|url=http://destinysearchproject.org/ |title= Destiny Search Project}}</ref> was formed in memory of Destiny Norton. The group is organized to assist with volunteer operations in missing persons cases.

The '''Julie Jensen case''' involves the trial of a [[Pleasant Prairie, Wisconsin|Pleasant Prairie]], [[Wisconsin]] man, Mark Jensen, on charges that he [[murder]]ed his wife, Julie Jensen on December 3, 1998. The case is notable for the eventual admission into [[evidence]] of a letter written by the deceased prior to her death, expressing suspicion of her husband's intentions.
Julie Jensen investigated her husband, checking his planner, photographing a note and documenting her suspicions.<ref name="cnn220208">{{cite news | last = Simon | first = Mallory | title = Jury: Letter from grave was 'road map' to murderer | work = CNN.com/crime | publisher = CNN | date = 25 February 2008 | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2008/CRIME/02/22/jensen.jurors/index.html | accessdate = }}</ref> She gave the letter to a neighbor with instructions to hand it to police if anything should happen to her. She wrote that she would never commit [[suicide]] and that if she died, police should consider her husband a suspect. "I pray that I am wrong and nothing happens, but I am suspicious of Mark's suspicious behaviors and fear for my early demise."<ref>{{cite news | last = Antlfinger | first = Carrie | title = Wis. jury hears dead wife's letter | work = USA Today | agency= Associated Press | date = 7 January 2008| url = https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2008-01-07-1500659240_x.htm | accessdate = }}</ref>
In 2008, Mark Jensen was convicted of [[first degree murder]] and sentenced to [[life imprisonment]] without the possibility of [[parole]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=O'Neill|first1=Anne|title=Husband guilty of murder in 'letter from grave' case|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/CRIME/02/21/jensen.verdict/|website=cnn.com|publisher=CNN|accessdate=25 May 2017}}</ref>, a verdict which was later overturned.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bohr|first1=Nick|title=Man accused of poisoning wife with antifreeze wins appeal|url=http://www.wisn.com/article/man-accused-of-poisoning-wife-with-antifreeze-wins-appeal/6328483|website=wisn.com|publisher=ABC 12 WISN|accessdate=25 May 2017}}</ref>
==Background== Julie Griffin was working at a [[Sears]] department store in [[Oshkosh, Wisconsin|Oshkosh]] when she met Mark Jensen in 1981. Both were students at a local college; Mark graduated but Julie did not. The couple moved to the [[Carol Beach, Wisconsin|Carol Beach]] neighborhood of [[Pleasant Prairie, Wisconsin]] and had two children, David and Douglas, aged 8 and 3 at the time of Julie's death.<ref>{{cite web |title=Timeline |url=http://www.oursisterjulie.com/Julie/Timeline.html |accessdate=25 May 2017}}</ref>{{better source|date=May 2017}} Julie was described as having a complicated family life (her mother was an alcoholic and her younger brother died in an accident as a toddler), but was a devoted mother to her children.{{cn|date=May 2017}} At the time of her death, Julie worked a part-time job for the Port Authority in [[Chicago]], while Mark Jensen was employed at a construction firm.{{cn|date=May 2017}}
==Trial== Special [[Prosecutor]] Robert Jambois contended that Mark Jensen poisoned his wife Julie, then 40, with [[ethylene glycol]] ([[antifreeze]]) and then suffocated her inside the garage of their home in [[Pleasant Prairie, Wisconsin|Pleasant Prairie]] on December 3, 1998. The trial was moved from [[Kenosha County, Wisconsin|Kenosha County]] to [[Walworth County, Wisconsin|Walworth County]] in response to pre-trial publicity. [[Defense (legal)|Defense]] counsel Craig Albee argued that Julie Jensen was a depressed woman who killed herself and framed her husband. Moreover, the deceased had seen a therapist at least three times for [[Major depressive disorder|depression]] and was aware of her husband's extramarital affair with a co-worker,<ref>{{cite web | title = Julie Jensen's Letter Points Finger at Mark | work = 620 WTMJ Newsradio | publisher = WTMJ | year = 2008 | url = http://www.620wtmj.com/news/local/45320097.html | accessdate = }}</ref> Kelly LaBonte Grieman whom Mark Jensen later married, and who assumed custody of the Jensens' two sons after Mark's eventual imprisonment. Evidence was introduced showing that Mark Jensen had discussed poisoning his wife with co-workers and a jailhouse associate, as well as searching on the [[internet]] for information relating to spousal murder and poisoning techniques. The prosecution contended further that Jensen remained angry over his wife's brief affair in 1991 with co-worker Perry Tarica.<ref>{{cite news | title = At Jensen trial, the other man takes the stand | work = CNN | date = 25 January 2008 | url = http://insession.blogs.cnn.com/2008/01/25/at-jensen-trial-the-other-man-takes-the-stand/ }}</ref> The letter's use by the prosecutors was controversial, because such evidence has been blocked from court for years by strict [[hearsay]] rules based on criminal defendants' right, under the [[Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Sixth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution]] to confront their accusers. But the [[Wisconsin Supreme Court]], guided by a [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] ruling ([[Crawford v Washington]] 541 U.S. 36 (2004)), created a hearsay exception that permitted the use of Julie Jensen's letter and statements as a [[dying declaration]] — that is, evidence of her state of mind at the time of her death.
The letter was the critical factor in the trial that ended on February 22, 2008. The jury found Jensen, 48, guilty of his wife's murder after more than 30 hours of deliberations. He was sentenced by Kenosha County Circuit Court Judge Bruce Schroeder on February 27, 2008 to life in prison with no chance of [[parole]].<ref name="cnn220208" /><ref name="cnn270208">{{cite news | title = Husband gets life without parole in 'letter from the grave' case | work = CNN.com/crime | publisher = CNN | date = 27 February 2008 | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2008/CRIME/02/27/jensen.sentence/index.html | accessdate = }}</ref>
== Appellate proceedings == On December 19, 2013, a federal judge overturned Jensen's conviction, and ordered he be released from prison within 90 days. The court agreed with Jensen's argument that the state's use of his dead wife's words violated his Constitutional right to confront witnesses testifying against him. The state of Wisconsin appealed the case, but in 2015 the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit]] upheld the district court's decision on September 8, 2015.<ref>http://media.ca7.uscourts.gov/cgi-bin/rssExec.pl?Submit=Display&Path=Y2015/D09-08/C:14-1380:J:Tinder:dis:T:fnOp:N:1617867:S:0</ref>
Prosecutors decided to retry Jensen for the murder of his wife in January 2016.<ref>"[http://fox6now.com/2016/01/06/wisconsin-man-convicted-in-wifes-death-could-go-free-after-bail-hearing Judge sets bail at $1.2M for Mark Jensen as he awaits retrial in 1998 death of his wife]". ''Fox6Now.com'', January 6, 2016.</ref><ref>Beverly Taylor. "[http://fox6now.com/2016/05/04/accused-of-killing-his-wife-with-antifreeze-retrial-of-mark-jensen-may-be-delayed-until-2017/ Accused of killing his wife with antifreeze, retrial of Mark Jensen may be delayed until 2017]". ''Fox6Now.com'', May 4, 2016.</ref> On September 1, 2017, Kenosha Circuit Judge Chad Kerkman reinstated Mark Jensen’s conviction.<ref>http://www.kenoshanews.com/news/local/mark-jensen-s-murder-conviction-reinstated/article_91a3bb47-6785-512d-a638-3c2aec308a59.html</ref>
